title: Quiz sees sales tumble again as Only Way is Essex favourite falls out of fashion
text:
Quiz shares fell further out of fashion on Friday as the clothing firm came clean on a 5 per cent drop in sales over the first half of the year.

The embattled company, a former Only Way is Essex favourite, said the performance at its shops and concessions was weaker-than-hoped amid 'very challenging' high street conditions, including a slump in footfall.

Its total half-year revenues came in at £63.3million, with even a 7 per cent jump in online sales failing to offset the 11 per cent decay on the high street.

Quiz reported a 5% drop in total group revenues to £63.3million in the first half of the year

The news sent shares down by nearly 3 per cent in early trading on Friday to 16p, although they recovered to close 1.65 per cent higher at 16.95p. In July last year, the stock sold for more than £2 a share.

The company insisted that the rate of decline at its physical stores has 'reduced in recent weeks' but added that it will consider some store closures as and when leases come up for renewal.

It follows the launch of a business review earlier this year, aimed at cutting costs and turning the company's fortunes around.

Quiz boss Tarak Ramzan said: 'Overall, the group's trading performance in the first half has been broadly in line with the board's expectations despite the difficult UK trading environment.'

He added: 'Whilst trading conditions are expected to remain challenging in the near term, the board remains confident that underpinned by Quiz's flexible business model and an increasing online focus, the group can return to sustainable profitable growth in the medium term.'

Quiz said the rate of decline at its physical stores has 'reduced in recent weeks'

It has been a torrid year for Quiz. Its shares have collapsed by more than 90 per cent to lows of just 13p in August amid a string of disappointing results and profit warnings.

The company, which floated on the London stock exchange in 2017, previously bemoaned a significant slowdown in shopper numbers as difficult trading conditions 'persisted'.

At its full-year results in June, Quiz admitted that its profits had shrunk to almost nothing.

A 97 per cent slide left it with earnings of just £0.2million - down from £8.5million a year earlier.

Arlene Ewing, investment manager at Brewin Dolphin, said: 'Investors will have a keen eye on the results of the root and branch review announced earlier in the year, particularly the company's plans for some of its units in costly shopping centres.

'There is, nevertheless, some significant work required to turn the tide at Quiz, making it self-sufficient and able to handle the shocks faced by the wider sector.'
